module.p: Anthropic commons nouns are common nouns that characterise classes of human individual.

Some important sub-classes of anthropic common nouns are –
Ethnonymic common nouns characterise a person in terms of their ethno-cultural heritage or lineage, eg. Gàidheal
Gael, Highlander, Leòdhasach
man from Lewis, Caimbeulach
a Campbell.
Occupational common nouns characterise a person in terms of the role or function they perform in the tribe/community/society.
Sectarian common nouns characterise a person in terms of their religious or philosophical identity of beliefs.
age-related – deugaire
teenager
Most derived anthropic common nouns are masculine in gender and hence characterise classes of male persons. Specifically feminine/female variants are formed with the prefix ban(a)-.
The suffix -(e)ar is often used to derive anthropic common nouns.
